Tweet text: New #blog post highlighting the #data within the @arcticdatactr! We spoke to (soon to be!) Dr. Yoko Kugo about her dataset that documents Yup'ik place names in the Iliamna Lake area. Read more: https://t.co/6ULjkioWYQ #SharingSciFri https://t.co/D326axSI5E

How we treat #wastewater is key in many different environments, but especially so in the #Arctic to prevent industrial #pollution. Read more from Russia on how sewage systems in remote Arctic #communities can be improved for wastewater treatment! https://t.co/2nzaIvjVKI #NewPaper https://t.co/V4BYUWPRBj

Bill Manley speaking on an @IARPCCollab team meeting about the biggest issue facing those wanting to use and reuse #Arctic #data - the lack of interoperability. The Polar Data Hackathon team is hoping to work on these issues! https://t.co/wjMZXpZPtz
Absolutely - with more education and better curation practices, #metadata can get more complete and more FAIR! https://t.co/Z0qcVfNQ3S

@ESIPfed @EuroGeosciences @theAGU @HartharnSam Our general answer is that it depends - we will store the outputs if the researcher feels like it will be useful for other researchers, and/or if the model results will be difficult to reproduce. Otherwise, we can just archive the #code & model inputs! #datahelpdesk #vEGU21

Huntington et al. discuss the importance of #bowhead #whales to #Indigenous peoples w/ a literature review & 5 accounts from Indigenous authors on #whaling. Read: https://t.co/sy1oYpH0dR & see more of his traditional knowledge work in the Bering Sea: https://t.co/sVkYB77TIK https://t.co/D3GVnbimVM
@ESIPfed @MarshallXMa @dtkb11 @EuroGeosciences @theAGU This is such a lovely visualization of data! #dataviz

Ocean currents concentrate tiny pieces of plastic (microfibers) in the #ArcticOcean, making it a "dead end" for these fibers; they sweep in on ocean currents & then don't sweep out. #Reduce #Reuse #Recycle - your plastic may go as far away as the #Arctic! https://t.co/1ezMgGeFS6 https://t.co/NeDB8Vj4m6

One way you can adopt good practice is by linking #citations to data you have (or others have) stored in the Arctic Data Center - here's our #blog post from late last year running through how to do that: https://t.co/GQTk8asP1L 
Congrats on the co-authorship, @metamattj! #data https://t.co/TOnlhZFa1Y

@KevinUBC From @sjeanetteclark & @jmultiflorum: It depends! Paper co-authors may have nothing to do w/ creating the dataset, & dataset authors may not be listed on the paper. Creators can base who is included based on some kind of framework like an authorship agreement. #datahelpdesk
If you missed the first one, that's okay - the next one is on  May 5th. Register here! https://t.co/0krWrQndoX https://t.co/xSJbXEhlap
A crucial #NewPaper on @FAIRsharing_org and @GidaGlobal CARE principles for #Indigenous #data futures. https://t.co/qRWidrvHaK

#FungiFriday: Historic wooden structures associated with early exploration of the #Arctic are in danger - they're being attacked by #fungi that are actively decaying the wood! Read more in this #NewPaper by @forestmycology et al: https://t.co/OepQRjn49j #OpenAccess https://t.co/usbTTEPHiv

And the last talk is from Martha Raynolds, discussing vegetation gradients and the Summer Warmth Index in lakes in #BaffinIsland. These are some lovely #DataVisualizations! #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/hfG6prXI2r

@isabellemahar_: what is the impact of morphometry (the size and shape of a lake) of #Arctic lakewater isotopes? Looks like surface area of the #lake impacts the summer surface water isotope composition rather than volume - likely due to mixing. #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/ZtbLl5SlJ3

Kurt Lindberg: Do #Arctic plants change their leaf wax production in response to #Climate? No - it seems that changes in measured wax reflect changes in the plant species present in a particular area through time instead. #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/HR9QcfyA3a

Next: @JedLenetsky speaking about the variability of water temperatures in the #BeringStrait - an important predictor of the timing of seasonal #SeaIce. They learned the Anadyr current's heat, not the atmosphere's, is the main reason for the temp variations. #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/zoLFCL1NOc

Next: Rajmund Przybylak uses high resolution #data to explain main drivers for early 20th c #Arctic warming using long term, daily #data from meteorological stations & 20th century reanalysis V3 data from @NOAA's Physical Sciences Lab. https://t.co/Ydu9Dqxx4A #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/ZVdrS3Fdiv

Next up: Mark Furze speaking about #sediment core records from the M’Clintock Channel, which shows a geological record of widespread #ice retreat and ice instability. Can serve as an analogue for future #ClimateChange in the poles. #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/kRZLKWxgs9

A good question from the audience: what did these communities want help with? Secure water & sanitation.  Kongiganak & Mekoryuk in #Alaska have 200-600 people & 2 showers, & they have to haul their own water...covid exposed many issues w these remote villages. #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/IabAX27oP1

The first talk this morning is coming from #NNA 
@ArcticTogether: @JulieBrighamGre speaking about co-production and creating partnerships with Indigenous communities in the age of covid as part of decolonizing research. "We did a lot of listening." #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/veNY8yTCRN

First up for the next session of #ArcticWorkshop50 is recent @arcticdatactr training participant @sarahecrump!  She's discussing sedimentary ancient DNA (sedaDNA), which tells us about when aquatic #plant community changes happened as a result of rapid #ClimateChange. https://t.co/vYslZRbruM

The keynote for this section was fantastic - discussion of how #climate models are missing subsea #permafrost emissions, and what that means for #policy by 
@Sara_Sayedi! #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/HZGb4R1tlf

And the last talk was us, highlighting the portals service and the ability for researchers to build collections of #data on the @arcticdatactr that are relevant for their work plus a customized project page with freeform pages & metrics. https://t.co/DLH6rEsHuF #ArcticWorkshop50 https://t.co/gOg2KMAJmh

The functionality for this service is massive - #metadata, #geoportal for spatial data viewing, guidance documents for help, the ability to link #tabular data, and more. Check it out - here's a video of what they're all about. https://t.co/VEjHuTNtjm #ArcticWorkshop50

The session continues with Simon Riopel speaking about the super exciting #Arctic Spatial Data Infrastructure for SEAMLESS sharing of #SpatialData across jurisdictions - with the goal of building a multidimensional digital Arctic. On how researchers can be impactful - "if there are not #Indigenous voices in the room, raise those voices. Nothing about us without us."

He also stressed the importance of the 4 Rs when working with Indigenous cultures: #respect, #reciprocity, #relationality (want to be a good partner to the community), and #relevance to the community's needs (co-creation).

He's speaking about #Indigenization as an alternative to #colonization - in which we work together to develop a shared story with newcomers to come into a relationship with the land. https://t.co/x5WCjFa0vV
"#CulturalIntelligence matters in how you approach Indigenous peoples and do work with them - commit to doing the work and having that cultural intelligence." https://t.co/8W5zr5J07E
